results.name: Smallest number which has exactly n different partitions as a sum of 4 squares x^2+y^2+z^2+t^2.
comment: Is it known that a(n) always exists? - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Dec 18 2006
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..1000
Index entries for sequences related to sums of squares
mathematica: kmin[n_] := If[n<5, 1, 10n](* empirical, should be lowered in case of doubt *);
a[n_] := a[n] = For[k=kmin[n], True, k++, If[Length[PowersRepresentations[ k, 4, 2]] == n, Return[k]]];
program: (PARI) cnt4sqr(n)={ local(cnt=0,t2) ; for(x=0,floor(sqrt(n)), for(y=x,floor(sqrt(n-x^2)), for(z=y,floor(n-x^2-y^2), t2=n-x^2-y^2-z^2 ; if( t2>=z^2 && issquare(n-x^2-y^2-z^2), cnt++ ; ) ; ) ; ) ; ) ; return(cnt) ; } A124978(n)= { local(a=1) ; while(1, if( cnt4sqr(a)==n, return(a) ; ) ; a++ ; ) ; } { for(n=1,100, print(n," ",A124978(n)) ; ) ; } - _R. J. Mathar_, Nov 29 2006
